title: Compact Latent Representation for Image Compression (CLRIC)
author: Ayman A. Ameen (Fraunhofer Institute for Integrated Circuits IIS), Thomas Richter (Fraunhofer Institute for Integrated Circuits IIS), Andre Kaup (Friedrich-Alexander University at Erlangen-Nurnberg), ...
relevance_why: The paper's approach of leveraging latent variables from existing generative models could inspire similar strategies in audio processing, especially for tasks involving latent representations in audio generation.
background: Image compression employing latent variable approaches allows effective representation of images at various quality levels using a single model instead of multiple.
contribution: This paper introduces a compact latent representation method to solve the inefficiencies of traditional image compression models, achieving comparable perceptual quality to state-of-the-art techniques while being resource-efficient.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous compression methods required separate models for different quality levels, which were resource-intensive and less adaptable.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes pretrained models and overfitted functions in latent space, enabling continuous quality adaptation without retraining separate models.

key_innovation: The method's unique application of overfitting a learnable function in the latent space substantially reduces computational complexity and enhances the perceptual quality of outputs.
real_world_impact: The framework provides significant resource savings and improved compression efficiency, which can lead to better applications in media streaming and storage.
limitations: The encoding process is resource-intensive and takes considerable time, which limits practicality for real-time scenarios.

new_terms.latent variable: A **latent variable** is an unobserved variable that influences observed variables, often used to represent hidden states in models.
